item.title: Data Science Near You

item.title: Fighting Influence Operations with Data Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Detecting influence operations with data science, and fighting back!
item.description: Jonathon talks with special guests C E Carey and Kris Shaffer about their research into “influence operations” – the propaganda campaigns that are changing the way conversations happen on Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, and the other places we hang out online. item.title: All Hail Our Robot Bartender Overlords
item.itunes:subtitle: Robot bartenders! Beer data!
item.description: The gang chats about beer data, robot bartenders, and debates whether the webserver nginx rhymes with “engine” or private parts. Also Jonathon totally butchers a French guy’s name, and embarrasses himself.
item.content:encoded: The gang chats about beer data, robot bartenders, and debates whether the webserver nginx rhymes with “engine” or private parts. Also Jonathon totally butchers a French guy’s name, and embarrasses himself.

item.title: Badasses Feel Like Imposters
item.itunes:subtitle: Chris and Vidya talk about their own experiences with imposter syndrome!

item.title: Data Science On The Silicon Beach
item.itunes:subtitle: San Diego data science!
item.description: This week we talk to Maksim Percherskiy, Chief Data Officer for the city of San Diego about his work to make the city better through through data science.
item.content:encoded: This week we talk to Maksim Percherskiy, Chief Data Officer for the city of San Diego about his work to make the city better through through data science.

item.itunes:author: Partially Derivative

item.title: Particle Physics and Machine Learning at CERN with Michael Kagan
item.itunes:subtitle: LHC data science and how CERN is using open source machine learning!
item.description: This week we talk with Michael Kagan. He’s a data scientist at CERN, where physicists and engineers are probing the fundamental structure of the universe. It’s Michael’s job to figure out how to use open source machine learning tools like scikit learn and TensorFlow in the pursuit of new particles...
item.content:encoded: This week we talk with Michael Kagan. He’s a data scientist at CERN, where physicists and engineers are probing the fundamental structure of the universe. It’s Michael’s job to figure out how to use open source machine learning tools like scikit learn and TensorFlow in the pursuit of new particles...
item.author: jonathon@goodattheinternet.com (Partially Derivative)
item.itunes:author: Partially Derivative
item.itunes:summary: This week we talk with Michael Kagan. He’s a data scientist at CERN, where physicists and engineers are probing the fundamental structure of the universe. It’s Michael’s job to figure out how to use open source machine learning tools like scikit learn and TensorFlow in the pursuit of new particles...

item.title: Learning, Cider, and Performance Art with Paco Nathan
item.itunes:subtitle: O'Reilly behind the scenes. Data science, learning, and more!
item.description: This week we talk with Paco Nathan, who runs Learning at O’Reilly Media – producers of Strata + Hadoop and OSCON conferences, along with some of the most notable books on programming and machine learning. Paco also makes his own cider!
item.content:encoded: This week we talk with Paco Nathan, who runs Learning at O’Reilly Media – producers of Strata + Hadoop and OSCON conferences, along with some of the most notable books on programming and machine learning. Paco also makes his own cider!

item.title: Aaron Swartz And The CFAA
item.itunes:subtitle: The tragic story of Aaron Swartz and the CFAA.
item.description: As a chance of pace, we take a moment to talk about the tragedy of Aaron Swartz and the broad powers of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.
item.content:encoded: As a chance of pace, we take a moment to talk about the tragedy of Aaron Swartz and the broad powers of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

item.title: Your Surveys Suck
item.itunes:subtitle: Turns out designing surveys is a real skill, and you probably don't have it.
item.description: This week we interview survey methodology expert Dr. Frauke Kreuter about how we can design better surveys and where people often fail. We promise that if you listen to this episode you will leave with tangible, applicable knowledge you didn’t have before. If you want to dig more into survey...
item.content:encoded: This week we interview survey methodology expert Dr. Frauke Kreuter about how we can design better surveys and where people often fail. item.title: Frogger Is The New Killer Robot
item.itunes:subtitle: The gang is back! This week, academic smackdowns, frogger AI, and more!
item.description: This week the gang is back with another episode! This week Jonathon discusses the academic smackdown between Riza Berkin and Yannick Versley, Vidya discovers that AI can make AI and we are all doomed, and Chris talks about algorithmic accountability and remembers that Frogger exists.
item.content:encoded: This week the gang is back with another episode! This week Jonathon discusses the academic smackdown between Riza Berkin and Yannick Versley, Vidya discovers that AI can make AI and we are all doomed, and Chris talks about algorithmic accountability and remembers that Frogger exists.

item.title: S2E14: The Model is Racist
item.itunes:subtitle: Quantifying the Alt-Right's Racism
item.description: Every now and again we get to do some of our research, and this week Jonathon explains some of the theory behind his recent look into the alt-right: a sprawling coalition of reactionary conservatives who have lobbied to make the United States more “traditional,” more “populist” and more white. More...

item.title: S2E13: Granger Than Fiction
item.itunes:subtitle: The Dark Web is the Diagon Alley of the Internet
item.description: There’s a new Harry Potter book? Are you Sirius? I would’ve Neville thought this was possible! Turns out it was written by a neural network, so JK Rowling probably isn’t out of a job. Plus Chris explains how high school statistics beat the Nazis in World War II, and Vidya...

item.title: S2E9: Data Science & Suicide Prevention
item.itunes:subtitle: Data science techniques for battling the suicide epidemic, with Glen Coppersmith, CEO of Qntfy.
item.description: We’re doing something a little different this week. Instead of covering the week’s data news, we’re looking at how data science is helping with the very serious problem of suicide prevention. Huge thanks to Glen Coppersmith, CEO of Qntfy, for helping us dig into this topic.
item.content:encoded: We’re doing something a little different this week. Instead of covering the week’s data news, we’re looking at how data science is helping with the very serious problem of suicide prevention. Huge thanks to Glen Coppersmith, CEO of Qntfy, for helping us dig into this topic.

item.title: S2E8: The Love Child of Princess Leia and Jabba the Hut
item.itunes:subtitle: Stopping spoilers with data science, robot Rembrandts, subway math and programming tips!
item.description: Spoiler alert! We stand with Ruth Toner, in solidarity against spoilers. Vidya discovers a robot that paints like Rembrandt – is it an artist? What is art? What is meaning? We’ll discuss. Plus, Chris has a Beautiful Mind moment and helps you avert the existential crisis that is waiting for...

item.title: S2E7: Tay! Artificial Intelligence! Racism! The Future!
item.itunes:subtitle: This week's episode is dedicated entirely to Tay, the racist Microsoft AI.
item.description: This week’s episode is dedicated entirely to Tay, the Microsoft chat bot who started her 1-day life making adorable meme jokes, and ended it praising Hitler. Tay’s demise is an ominous warning about a future dominated by amoral robot overlords, and also comedy gold!
item.content:encoded: This week’s episode is dedicated entirely to Tay, the Microsoft chat bot who started her 1-day life making adorable meme jokes, and ended it praising Hitler. Tay’s demise is an ominous warning about a future dominated by amoral robot overlords, and also comedy gold!

item.title: S2E6: Robot Sex and Flappy Bird Vengeance
item.itunes:subtitle: The future of AI is funny and creepy
item.description: This week we explore the future of artificial intelligence by discussing robot sex at length. Chris seems pretty into it, not that we’re judging. Also Minecraft for AI experiments and humanity’s epic triumph over the most obnoxious iPhone game ever created.

item.title: S2E5: The Double Entendre
item.itunes:subtitle: Vidya hates wedding planning, Jonathon revels in scandal, and Chris washes his hair.
item.description: Vidya hates wedding planning, Jonathon could’ve talked about the rise of our Go-playing robot overlords, algorithmically predicting police misconduct or the biggest polling upset in political history, but instead digs into the crossword scandal of the century (here’s the GitHub repo). Chris was busy washing his hair or something, but he’ll...

item.title: S2E4: Naughty Millennials, Star Wars and Zombies!
item.itunes:subtitle: Millennials are staying married longer, the expanded Star Wars universe and invented childhood allergies.
item.description: We learn that millennials are staying married longer, you can go really deep down the Star Wars rabbit hole, and all your so-called allergies were made up by your parents. Also we talk to epidemiologist Eric Lofgren about how humanity can survive the zombie apocalypse.
item.content:encoded: We learn that millennials are staying married longer, you can go really deep down the Star Wars rabbit hole, and all your so-called allergies were made up by your parents. Also we talk to epidemiologist Eric Lofgren about how humanity can survive the zombie apocalypse.

item.title: S2E3: Chris Looks at Your Search History
item.itunes:subtitle: Data science watches you at work, plus data-driven parking discovery and an interview with Eliot Higgins, founder of Bellingcat.
item.description: We’re back! The latest nerdy data news, some beer, and a look how open data is used to fight crime and corruption. Jonathon is drinking Austin Eastciders, Chris is drinking a Nitro IPA, and we’re talking about corporate big brother sucking up your work data, plus Miguel Garrido’s epic, data-driven...

item.title: S2E2: Mind Control and Parasites
item.itunes:subtitle: Data scientists as parasites, snowpocalypse, and identifying people based only on their thoughts.
item.description: Data scientists are parasites, Snowpocalypse (or is it?), and an important public safety announcement from Chris about jogging and sterilization. Plus we talk to Dr. Sarah Laszlo about how she uses brainwaves like fingerprints to identify people based only on their thoughts.

item.title: S2E1: Do it LIVE!
item.itunes:subtitle: Chris and Jonathon record in front of a live audience at the StitchFix offices in San Francisco

item.itunes:subtitle: We talk with notable astrophysicists, cosmologists and astronauts to learn more about the data of space, dark matter and the early universe.

item.title: S1E35: The Data of Journalism
item.itunes:subtitle: We talk with the New York Times, Financial Times and ProPublica about how data investigation and interactive storytelling are changing journalism.
item.description: Data journalism and interactive storytelling have fundamentally changed the way we understand and consume the news. This week we’re talking to three leaders in the data journalism revolution, Martin Stabe, the head of interactive news at the Financial Times, Sisi Wei, a journalist and news apps developer at ProPublica, and...
item.content:encoded: Data journalism and interactive storytelling have fundamentally changed the way we understand and consume the news. item.title: S1E34: The Data of Sports
item.itunes:subtitle: Three famous sports analysts tell us how sports are being fundamentally changed by data and data science!
item.description: We’re joined by sports analytics luminaries Sean Lahman, author of the Lahman Baseball Database, Trey Causey, creator of The Spread, a blog about the data science of sports, and Greg Matthews, author of openWAR, a technique for predicting the worth of baseball players. We dig into how huge amounts of data...
item.content:encoded: We’re joined by sports analytics luminaries Sean Lahman, author of the Lahman Baseball Database, Trey Causey, creator of The Spread, a blog about the data science of sports, and Greg Matthews, author of openWAR, a technique for predicting the worth of baseball players. We dig into how huge amounts of data...

item.title: S1E33: Data of the Impossible
item.itunes:subtitle: Exploding atoms, baby universes, and the foundation of existence. We talk to a CERN physicist about finding the Higgs Boson, and a theoretical physicist about time before the Big Bang.
item.description: The data of colliding atoms, baby universes and the foundation of our existence. We talk with internationally renowned researchers Dr. Kyle Cranmer, one of experimental particle physicists responsible for discovering the elusive Higgs Boson, and Dr. Lee Smolin, one of the theoretical physicists behind Loop quantum gravity, and author of...

item.title: S1E32: The Data of Politics
item.itunes:subtitle: The CTO of the Republicans and Director of Data Science for the Democrats talk politics, data and how elections are won.
item.description: We talk politics with the top data scientists in the Republican and Democratic parties. Plus job announcements, data conference discounts, and Jonathon’s triumphant return to hosting duties!

item.itunes:subtitle: Is there data in love? Are there numbers in sex? We'll find out. Also we go behind the scenes at a craft brewery.
item.description: Is there really data in love? Can we quantify sex? Find out this week! Also, we go behind the scenes at craft brewery Thirsty Planet.

item.title: S1E27: Robots Are Racist
item.itunes:subtitle: Christina Warren from Mashable and Google's machine learning misfires.
item.description: We interview the amazing Christina Warren! Check out her work on Mashable, and two great podcasts – Overtired and Rocket. Also we’re in Portland this week, and grabbing beer at the White Owl Social Club around 5:30 on Wednesday. Swing by if you’re free!

item.title: S1E26: The Big Reveal
item.itunes:subtitle: We interview Hunter Walk from Homebrew, and Chris drinks horrible beer.
item.description: This week we interview Hunter Walk, cofounder of Homebrew (check him out on Twitter), and Vidya joins us again to announce our brand-spanking new startup, Popily!

item.title: S1E5: The Remarkably Sober One
item.itunes:subtitle: This week, a drink-less Jonathon and Chris once again delve into the world of data science, exploring the identification of moody music, making Star Wars API pulls, why diversity is a competitive advantage, and much more.

item.title: S1E4: The One Where Chris Unfriends Jonathon
item.itunes:subtitle: With Thanksgiving in the past, this week the Partially Derivative crew discusses how data science knows when you are quitting your job, spreading lies, and much more.

item.itunes:subtitle: In this week's episode, Jonathon and Chris tackle using data and algorithms in lawsuits, a way to describe a picture in less than a thousand words, how to dominate your pickup basketball game with data science, and much more. Grab a cold drink and enjoy.
